March 13, 2011: Fiction
TREACHERY IN DEATH, by J. D. Robb. (Putnam, $26.95.) Eve Dallas and her
partner, Peabody, investigate a grocer’s murder.
PALE DEMON, by Kim Harrison. (Harper Voyager/HarperCollins, $26.99.) The witch
Rachel Morgan has three days to clear her name; Book 9 in the Hollows series.
GIDEON’S SWORD, by Douglas Preston and Lincoln Child. (Grand Central,
$26.99.) Gideon Crew avenges his father’s death and is sent on a mission by a
government contractor.
A DISCOVERY OF WITCHES, by Deborah Harkness. (Viking, $28.95.) The
recovery of a lost ancient manuscript in a library at Oxford sets a fantastical
underworld stirring.
TICK TOCK, by James Patterson and Michael Ledwidge. (Little, Brown, $27.99.)
The New York detective Michael Bennett enlists the help of a former colleague to
solve a rash of horrifying crimes that are throwing the city into chaos.
THE GIRL WHO KICKED THE HORNET’S NEST, by Stieg Larsson. (Knopf,
$27.95.) The third volume of the Millennium trilogy, about a Swedish hacker and a
journalist.
THE UNION QUILTERS, by Jennifer Chiaverini. (Dutton, $24.95.) Members of a
quilting circle protect their homes and families during the Civil War; an Elm Creek
Quilts novel.
THE HELP, by Kathryn Stockett. (Amy Einhorn/Putnam, $24.95.) A young white
woman and two black maids in 1960s Mississippi.
THE PARIS WIFE, by Paula McLain. (Ballantine, $25.) Ernest Hemingway’s first
wife, Hadley, narrates this novel set in Paris.
NIGHT VISION, by Randy Wayne White. (Putnam, $25.95.) Doc Ford must find a
young girl from Guatemala who disappears after witnessing a murder.
DEVIL’S FOOD CAKE MURDER, by Joanne Fluke. (Kensington, $24.) Hannah
Swensen discovers that a dead clergyman was not all he seemed; recipes included.
DEAD OR ALIVE, by Tom Clancy with Grant Blackwood. (Putnam, $28.95.) Familiar
Clancy characters appear as an intelligence group tracks a vicious terrorist called
the Emir.
ROOM, by Emma Donoghue. (Little, Brown, $24.99.) A mother’s prison is her young
son’s entire world.
THE CONFESSION, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $28.95.) A criminal wants to
save an innocent man on death row, but he must convince the authorities he’s
March 13, 2011
Non-Fiction
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $27.) An Olympic runner’s
story of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
KNOWN AND UNKNOWN, by Donald Rumsfeld. (Sentinel, $36.) The former
defense secretary’s memoir discusses his role in the invasion and occupation of
Iraq.
DECISION POINTS, by George W. Bush. (Crown, $35.) The former president’s
memoir discusses his Christianity, the end of his drinking and his decisions on
9/11, Iraq and Katrina.
AGAINST ALL ODDS, by Scott Brown. (Harper/HarperCollins, $27.99.) The
senator from Massachusetts describes his life of hardship and second chances.
CLEOPATRA, by Stacy Schiff. (Little, Brown, $29.99.) The last queen of ancient
Egypt was ambitious, audacious and formidably intelligent.
BATTLE HYMN OF THE TIGER MOTHER, by Amy Chua. (Penguin Press,
$25.95.) A Chinese-American mother makes a case for strict and demanding
parenting.
I BEAT THE ODDS, by Michael Oher with Don Yaeger. (Gotham, $26.) This
memoir by the Baltimore Ravens offensive tackle describes how he broke out of
the tough streets of Memphis and into a world of opportunity.
A WIDOW’S STORY, by Joyce Carol Oates. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $27.99.) The
prolific author describes her struggle to comprehend a life without her husband.
UNDISPUTED, by Chris Jericho with Peter Thomas Fornatale. (Grand Central,
$27.99.) The former World Wrestling Entertainment champ continues the story of
his career.
THE IMMORTAL LIFE OF HENRIETTA LACKS, by Rebecca Skloot. (Crown,
$26.) The story of a woman whose cancer cells were cultured without her
permission in 1951.
LIFE, by Keith Richards with James Fox. (Little, Brown, $29.99.) The Rolling
Stones guitarist’s revealing autobiography is also a portrait of the era when rock ‘n’
roll came of age.
THE PIONEER WOMAN, by Ree Drummond. (Morrow/HarperCollins, $25.99.)
The proprietor of ThePioneerWoman.com describes her marriage.
THE HIDDEN REALITY, by Brian Greene. (Knopf, $29.95.) A physicist explains
various theories involving the existence of parallel universes.
